content:
Hi! I am a second year Masters of Science in Robotics student at the University of Pennsylvania. I had previously done my undergraduate studies at the National Institute of Technology Karnataka, India. There, I had majored in Mechanical Engineering. My areas of interests are in the control systems and application of machine learning like reinforcement learning and computer vision for robots. I have worked on projects in the domains of manipulator, aerial and ground robotics. I am also interested in localization and mapping, controls, motion and path planning and mechanical design.
During my free time, I read books, draw and listen to music. I read a lot of non-fiction books, particularly relating to anthropology, world history and current affairs. I am a massive F1 and endurance racing fan. In my free time, I like to sketch designs of cars, listen to music and watch football (soccer) matches. My favorite genre of music is Indie Rock/Pop and Garage Rock. My favorite artists/bands are The Strokes, Arctic Monkeys, and the Killers.
summary: Hi! I am a second year Masters of Science in Robotics student at the University of Pennsylvania. I had previously done my undergraduate studies at the National Institute of Technology Karnataka, India.
title: Venkat Varun Velpula

summary: Implemented the YOLO algorithm for the purpose of object recognition of cars, humans and traffic lights from a dataset of more than 3000 images.
title: YOLO algorithm for object recognition in images

summary: Explored the application of learning for predicting future trajectories of swarms by approximating the non-linear dynamics of swarm models. Methods from data-driven techniques like SINDy, complex learning methods like CNNs, RNNs, and NeuralODE were tested. Experiments were carried out for both steady state and transient dynamics.
title: Learning Interactions and Dynamics of Swarms

summary: Augmented the vanilla RRT* path planning algorithm for dynamic environment by implementing replanning of paths through regrowth of nodes and reconnection to original tree. This method of dynamic path planning decreased time of convergence to optimal path by almost 15 times over vanilla RRT* implementation.
title: RRT* path planning for robot in dynamic environments

summary: Implemented a mapping and localization algorithm for the THOR-OP robot operated on the 4th floor of Levine Building here at UPenn. The mapping and localization was applied by using information from inertial, odometery and LIDAR sensor data to build a 2D occupancy grid map of teh walls and obstacles in the environemnt.
title: Predicting success of a crowdfunded project on Kickstrater platform

summary: Implemented an Unscented Kalman Filter for orientation tracking of quadcopters. The data given was that of IMU (accelerometer and gyroscope). The results of the UKF was compared with the ground truth position data which was obtained from a motion capture system.
title: Unscented Kalman Filter to track robot position in 3D space

summary: Performed regression to predict the amount of money a project can get funded for, and classification analysis to predict whether the project could successfully raise the quoted funding target given the project details. Combined dataset from Kaggle and data scrapped from Kickstarter website to obtain a dataset of 69210 projects, which contained new features like the number of pictures, textual description of projects, etc.
title: Predicting success of a crowdfunded project on Kickstrater platform

summary: Improved paths generated by probabilistic planners like RRT using shortcutting heurestics and acceleration bounding of joints for manipulator robots.
title: Trajectory Smoothening for Probabilistic Planners

summary: An experiement to determine the search effectiveness of a camera for search applications using a downward facing camera mounted on an UAV. The model captures the spatial variation of the camera in terms of its effectiveness in target detection.
title: On effectiveness of camera on an UAV mounted search sensor

summary: Developed control of multi-quadcopters systems for indoor environment using PID tuners and by implementing sensor fusion on the data from motion capture system and IMU sensors. Guidance laws like Pure Pursuit and Good Helmsman, and tracking laws were tested on this developed platform.
title: Control of quadcopters in an indoor environment

summary: Developed of a mock model of a smart city incorporating concepts in Internet of Things, sensors and sctuators, computer vision and path planning as part of a team of twenty students over an entire semester. Further, I personally developed the module and code for the detection and localization of the Autonomous Ground Vehicles (AGVs) and buildings using an overhead camera through the detection of AruCo markers.
title: Smart City

summary: Part of the mechanical team responsible design for the chassis, gripper and other key mechanisms for the robots on SolidWorks and performed kinematic analyses of the designed mechanisms. In the competition, we won the team award for the 'Best Use of Matlab'. We had used Matlab to establish the inverse kinematic equations for the mobile robots which were using Mecanum and Omni wheel configurations.
title: ABU Robocon Robotics Competition

summary: Designed a novel Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT) incorporating positive drive. The design enables for good fuel economy for high torque applications like in trucks and buses.
title: Positive Drive Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT)
